body: The plugin is only shipped with the compiler internal headers. While the compiler supports c++11 features, I guess you'll have to download and add any updated headers to the search path manually. I haven't done this myself, but will leave the issue open in case someone has and can provide more details.

Most of the C++11 support also needs the "-stdlib=libc++" argument additional to "-std=C++11" (for example see here: http://marshall.calepin.co/llvmclang-and-standard-libraries-on-mac-os-x.html ). I am able to successfully compile code involving the use of std::shared_ptr<> when I include both of these flags on my system. However, the "-stdlib=libc++" flag causes SublimeClang plugin fail to find C++ headers (i.e. iostream, list, memory, ...). I did replace the compiler headers shipped with the plugin with the ones from my system (Clang 4.0), and I also replaced libclang.dylib with the one from my system. No good. Same issue. Not passing "-stdlib=libc++" argument causes the plugin fail to trigger C++11 support, this is expected. However, including "-stdlib=libc++" argument still causes the plugin fail to find headers (all C++ headers).

Ok, here is a little bit more insight into the problem. 

Test1.cpp contents:
```C++
#include <memory>

int main(int argc, char const *argv[])
{
	std::shared_ptr<int> (new int);
	return 0;
}
```

Compiling with the following command from the terminal:
```
clang++ -v -fshow-source-location -std=c++11 -stdlib=libc++ test1.cpp -o test1
```
produces the following output, and successfully compiles:
```
Apple clang version 4.0 (tags/Apple/clang-421.0.57) (based on LLVM 3.1svn)
Target: x86_64-apple-darwin12.0.0
Thread model: posix
 "/usr/bin/clang" -cc1 -triple x86_64-apple-macosx10.8.0 -emit-obj -mrelax-all -disable-free -disable-llvm-verifier -main-file-name test1.cpp -pic-level 1 -mdisable-fp-elim -relaxed-aliasing -masm-verbose -munwind-tables -target-cpu core2 -target-linker-version 133.3 -v -resource-dir /usr/bin/../lib/clang/4.0 -fmodule-cache-path /var/folders/y0/h3vnt33x189dw5dzxfcxs1dr0000gn/T/clang-module-cache -stdlib=libc++ -std=c++11 -fdeprecated-macro -fdebug-compilation-dir /Dummy/Test1 -ferror-limit 19 -fmessage-length 122 -stack-protector 1 -mstackrealign -fblocks -fobjc-runtime-has-arc -fobjc-runtime-has-weak -fobjc-dispatch-method=mixed -fobjc-default-synthesize-properties -fcxx-exceptions -fexceptions -fdiagnostics-show-option -fcolor-diagnostics -o /var/folders/y0/h3vnt33x189dw5dzxfcxs1dr0000gn/T/test1-MbkCSA.o -x c++ test1.cpp
clang -cc1 version 4.0 based upon LLVM 3.1svn default target x86_64-apple-darwin12.0.0
ignoring nonexistent directory "/usr/include/c++/v1"
ignoring nonexistent directory "/usr/local/include"
#include "..." search starts here:
#include <...> search starts here:
 /usr/bin/../lib/c++/v1
 /usr/bin/../lib/clang/4.0/include
 /usr/include
 /System/Library/Frameworks (framework directory)
 /Library/Frameworks (framework directory)
End of search list.
 "/usr/bin/ld" -demangle -dynamic -arch x86_64 -macosx_version_min 10.8.0 -o test1 /var/folders/y0/h3vnt33x189dw5dzxfcxs1dr0000gn/T/test1-MbkCSA.o -lc++ -lSystem /usr/bin/../lib/clang/4.0/lib/darwin/libclang_rt.osx.a
```

Similarly, changing the shared_ptr to auto_ptr in test1.cpp, and compiling it with the following command:
```
clang++ -v -fshow-source-location  test1.cpp -o test1
```
also successfully compiles (without c++11 support as expected), producing the following output:
```
Apple clang version 4.0 (tags/Apple/clang-421.0.57) (based on LLVM 3.1svn)
Target: x86_64-apple-darwin12.0.0
Thread model: posix
 "/usr/bin/clang" -cc1 -triple x86_64-apple-macosx10.8.0 -emit-obj -mrelax-all -disable-free -disable-llvm-verifier -main-file-name test1.cpp -pic-level 1 -mdisable-fp-elim -relaxed-aliasing -masm-verbose -munwind-tables -target-cpu core2 -target-linker-version 133.3 -v -resource-dir /usr/bin/../lib/clang/4.0 -fmodule-cache-path /var/folders/y0/h3vnt33x189dw5dzxfcxs1dr0000gn/T/clang-module-cache -fdeprecated-macro -fdebug-compilation-dir /Dummy/Test1 -ferror-limit 19 -fmessage-length 122 -stack-protector 1 -mstackrealign -fblocks -fobjc-runtime-has-arc -fobjc-runtime-has-weak -fobjc-dispatch-method=mixed -fobjc-default-synthesize-properties -fcxx-exceptions -fexceptions -fdiagnostics-show-option -fcolor-diagnostics -o /var/folders/y0/h3vnt33x189dw5dzxfcxs1dr0000gn/T/test1-jZw3HK.o -x c++ test1.cpp
clang -cc1 version 4.0 based upon LLVM 3.1svn default target x86_64-apple-darwin12.0.0
ignoring nonexistent directory "/usr/include/c++/4.2.1/i686-apple-darwin10/x86_64"
ignoring nonexistent directory "/usr/include/c++/4.0.0"
ignoring nonexistent directory "/usr/include/c++/4.0.0/i686-apple-darwin8/"
ignoring nonexistent directory "/usr/include/c++/4.0.0/backward"
ignoring nonexistent directory "/usr/local/include"
#include "..." search starts here:
#include <...> search starts here:
 /usr/include/c++/4.2.1
 /usr/include/c++/4.2.1/backward
 /usr/bin/../lib/clang/4.0/include
 /usr/include
 /System/Library/Frameworks (framework directory)
 /Library/Frameworks (framework directory)
End of search list.
 "/usr/bin/ld" -demangle -dynamic -arch x86_64 -macosx_version_min 10.8.0 -o test1 /var/folders/y0/h3vnt33x189dw5dzxfcxs1dr0000gn/T/test1-jZw3HK.o -lstdc++ -lSystem /usr/bin/../lib/clang/4.0/lib/darwin/libclang_rt.osx.a
```

The differences in the above two outputs show that; without c++11 support, the compiler includes:
```
/usr/include/c++/4.2.1
/usr/include/c++/4.2.1/backward
```
with c++11 support, the compiler includes:
```
/usr/lib/c++/v1
```
among other include directories shared by both configurations. Everything seems fine and working with the compiler itself.

Now, the strage thing with the plugin is that, when I pass '/usr/include/c++/4.2.1' and '/usr/include/c++/4.2.1/backward' as include directories in SublimeClang options, everything is fine and the plugin supports std::auto_ptr code completion. But if I pass '/usr/lib/c++/v1' as the include directory, then the plugin neither supports std::shared_ptr code completion, nor it supports std::auto_ptr code completion. It does find the headers, and it does not show any errors related to the use of std::auto_ptr or std::shared_ptr though. Seems like there is only a problem with the code completion which I couldn't figure out yet.

These are the include dirs I have to add to get the -std=c++11 and -stdlib=libc++ lib flags working:

> /usr/lib/c++/v1
> /usr/include/c++/4.2.1
> /usr/include/c++/4.2.1/ext

Without the last dir I couldn't include type_traits
Closing as there's no action that should be taken SublimeClang side. Please reopen with more details if you think I'm mistaken.

The libc++ library is part of llvm suit. With Xcode installed, the libc++ library already was installed in the system in /usr/lib/c++/v1, which is fully c++11 conformal now. However SublimeClang does not set the path for this library in default, which makes the static analyse and build giving false alarm. This should be fixed.

Under Mac I had a problem with a file using c++11 unique_ptr. I commented out the following line from general settings under the "options" item:
``` "-isystem", "/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.7.sdk/usr/include/c++/4.2.1" ```
(which seem to point to old version of the memory header) and added
```
	"additional_language_options":
	{
		"c++" :
		[
			"-std=c++11",
			"-stdlib=libc++",
			"-Wno-c++11-extensions",
			"-isystem", "/usr/lib/c++/v1",
			"-isystem", "/usr/include/c++/4.2.1",
			"-isystem", "/usr/include/c++/4.2.1/ext"
		],
		"c": [],
		"objc": [],
		"objc++": []
	}
```
into user settings what finally solved my problem is solved.
